raw_data.title: Engineering Managers II
raw_data.description: An Engineering Manager II manages the activities of an engineering group in support of large, complex, and multi-facility project development that include 10+ years of energy savings and performance guarantees. An Engineering Manager II ensures his/her functional group is developing its projects in accordance with requirements and standards, including intimate knowledge of FAR, DFARS, and all governing measurement & verification requirements. Extremely high priority of ensuring they perform engineering work on schedule and within budget due to the criticality of the customer’s mission. This includes providing support and guidance during the engineering process to develop a project scope of work, accurate cost estimates consistent with the scope of work, compliance with FARS, DFARS and other laws, savings calculations based on documented baselines, appropriate assumptions, and to develop the technical framework for energy savings guarantees. An Engineering Manager II provides guidance, advice, historical business knowledge and oversight to their direct reports to ensure the projects are executed per ESG and customer requirements and standards. An Engineering Manager II works with his/her peer group to ensure obligations are being met and tracked and are in compliance with appropriate contracting standards for the development, execution, and performance period services provided.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: 7  years related experience preferably in government performance contracting. Two years management experience. (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

labor_categories.years_experience: 7  years related experience preferably in government performance contracting. Two years management experience. (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

raw_data.title: Operations Managers I
raw_data.description: An Operations Manager provides direct managerial support to two or more Operations Teams made up of Project Managers and Construction Managers. The Operations Manager directs and coordinates activities of the operations personnel and consultants to ensure projects are on schedule and within prescribed budgets. The Operations Manager provides guidance and advice in the selection of the subcontractors and vendors to deliver the project per ESG  customer requirements and standards, coordinates with governmental regulatory agencies, and works with the M&V department to ensure the obligations are being met and tracked appropriately.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Three (3) years related experience in performance contracting in the delivery side and two years management experience (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

labor_categories.years_experience: Three (3) years related experience in performance contracting in the delivery side and two years management experience (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

raw_data.title: Project Managers, Senior
raw_data.description: A Project Manager, Senior serves as the customer’s single point-of-contact and leads the project team through project development, formal risk analysis, design and construction activities, and follow-on services. The Project Manager, Senior develops customer requirements and manage the project’s budget, schedule, and scope. The Project Manager, Senior oversees all aspects of installation including quality control and commissioning and works with all parties involved to proactively prevent and solve problems that may arise in the course of the project. This position leads the development of the acquisition, project management, and safety plans, proposal development, and project financing activities. A Project Manager, Senior manages and directs both internal and external labor resources and is ultimately responsible for project performance and overall customer satisfaction.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Ten to fifteen years of engineering and construction-related experience (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

labor_categories.years_experience: Ten to fifteen years of engineering and construction-related experience (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

raw_data.title: Project Managers II
raw_data.description: A Project Manager II serves as an energy performance contracting customer’s single point-of-contact and leads the skilled project team through project development, formal risk analysis, design and construction activities, and follow-on services of large, complex multi-facility projects that requires significant travel. A Project Manager II develops customer requirements and manages the project’s budget, schedule, and scope for mission critical customers.  A Project Manager II oversees all aspects of project installation including quality control and commissioning and works with all parties involved to proactively prevent and solve problems that may arise in the course of the project. This position leads the development of the acquisition, project management, compliance with FAR and / or DFARS, and safety plans, proposal development, and project financing activities. A Project Manager II manages and directs both internal and external labor resources and is ultimately responsible for project performance and overall customer satisfaction.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Minimum one year construction related experience or five years’ experience in the construction industry including exposure to project development, working with and directing project teams and developing schedules

labor_categories.years_experience: Minimum one year construction related experience or five years’ experience in the construction industry including exposure to project development, working with and directing project teams and developing schedules

A Project Manager oversees all aspects of project installation including quality control and commissioning and works with all parties involved to proactively prevent and solve problems that may arise in the course of the project. This position leads the development of the acquisition, project management, and safety plans, proposal development, and project financing activities. A Project Manager manages and directs both internal and external labor resources and is ultimately responsible for project performance and overall customer satisfaction.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Minimum one year construction related experience or five years’ experience in the construction industry including exposure to project development, working with and directing project teams and developing schedules; Demonstrated working knowledge of OSHA, Federal and State Safety regulations; (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

raw_data.title: Construction Managers II
raw_data.description: A Construction Manager II has overall responsibility for ensuring the successful implementation of large, multi-facility, complex, construction projects on time and within budget due to the mission criticality of the customer’s site. The Construction Manager II oversees all project construction activities including management of subcontractors and vendors, equipment installation, customer communications, monitoring the quality and the safety of the subcontractors, and ensuring adherence to OSHA standards.  A construction manager II will have heavy travel requirements and must be familiar with all FAR, DFARS, and measurement & verification requirements.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Minimum Three years Construction experience

labor_categories.years_experience: Minimum Three years Construction experience

raw_data.title: Construction Managers I
raw_data.description: A Construction Manager has overall responsibility for ensuring the successful construction of  construction projects on time and within budget. The Construction Manager oversees all  project construction activities including management of subcontractors and vendors, equipment installation, customer communications, monitoring quality and the safety of the subcontractors, and ensuring adherence to OSHA standards.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Minimum Three years Construction experience; CEM is preferred

labor_categories.years_experience: Minimum Three years Construction experience; CEM is preferred

raw_data.title: Safety Managers
raw_data.description: A Safety Manager serves as Site Safety and Health Officer (SSHO) on a variety of construction projects ensuring that all project activities are conducted with all applicable OSHA requirements and regulations, and Safety and Health requirements found in the EM 385-1-1 (November 30, 2014 edition). A Safety Manager implements the Accident Prevention Plan and directs compliance activities for all personnel, performs site inspections, site orientations, develops Activity Hazard Analyses (AHAs), and performs incident investigations with Root Cause Analysis. The Safety Manager also serves as a “Competent and/or Qualified Person” for activities including, but not necessarily limited to, fall protection, confined space entry, scaffolding, hot work, lockout/tagout, PPE, etc.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years of continuous occupational safety experience in the construction industry supervising or managing safety programs, safety processes, and conducting hazard analyses and controls. Prefer proven understanding of related federal safety requirements and best practices. (or equivalent combination of experience and education)
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Instructor-signed OSHA 30-hour General Industry or Construction Industry training card, EM 385-1-1 (November 30, 2014 edition).

labor_categories.years_experience: Five years of continuous occupational safety experience in the construction industry supervising or managing safety programs, safety processes, and conducting hazard analyses and controls. Prefer proven understanding of related federal safety requirements and best practices. (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

raw_data.title: Business Ops Support
raw_data.description: Business Operations Support personnel includes one or more of the following disciplines:Contracts Management personnel oversee the development and implementation of business customer contracts including  performance contracts, remaining responsible for contract(s) and respective documentation from solicitation to closeout.  Procurement personnel are responsible for the overall sourcing strategy for projects including acquisition planning, supplier qualification, negotiations, regulatory compliance, contract management, supplier relationship management, and fulfillment of the Small Business subcontracting plan. Finance personnel oversee the project financing process using cost and savings data to develop economic models for energy conservation and other projects including profitability and cash flow analyses, draw and payment schedules, and other required contract documentations.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Three to fifteen years related experience depending on specific sub-function and management level.

labor_categories.years_experience: Three to fifteen years related experience depending on specific sub-function and management level.

raw_data.title: Contracts Management
raw_data.description: The Manager, Contracts & Compliance is responsible for contract management of projects as well as ensuring compliance with Statutory Provisions, Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) and Standard Business Operating Procedures.

raw_data.title: Facility Operations Directors
raw_data.description: The Facility Operations Director is responsible for oversight of facility management, energy delivery, and operations and maintenance (O&M) services at multiple (typically >10) customer and/or company owned facilities some of which operate on a 24 x 7 basis. Responsible for delivering favorable results in Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS), financial, customer service, continuous improvement, supporting business growth, and employee development while ensuring all contractual requirements are met. Responsible for meeting all customer service, contractual requirements, and guarantees at each facility. Represent organization to community, customers, government agencies and the public.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Ten (10) or more years managerial experience supervising a technical staff (supervisors, technicians); Prior multi-plant management experience and management of a large facility (100 people or more); Prior responsibility for P&L; Experience leading plant start-ups; Project and/or construction management experience; Demonstrated experience and success with operating and maintenance processes of new and upgraded facilities, including: steam, chilled water, electrical, power generation, heat recovery, and control systems, HVAC, biogas operations.

labor_categories.years_experience: Ten (10) or more years managerial experience supervising a technical staff (supervisors, technicians); Prior multi-plant management experience and management of a large facility (100 people or more); Prior responsibility for P&L; Experience leading plant start-ups; Project and/or construction management experience; Demonstrated experience and success with operating and maintenance processes of new and upgraded facilities, including: steam, chilled water, electrical, power generation, heat recovery, and control systems, HVAC, biogas operations.

raw_data.title: Facility Managers, Senior1
raw_data.description: The Senior Facilities Manager is responsible for delivering results related to EHS, financial performance, equipment reliability and efficiency, customer satisfaction, and employee training and development. Creates and maintains positive customer relations. This individual must have an in-depth technical understanding of and practical experience with energy distribution, production, and components associated with various systems including heating, ventilation, air conditioning, compressed air, boilers, chillers, refrigeration systems, etc. This individual provides leadership and guidance in addition to technical support for all facility operations and employees and is capable of managing complex sites and contractual agreements. This manager establishes performance expectations at both the employee and facility levels.  Provides proper tracking and recordkeeping for various facility, customer, and corporate reports.

labor_categories.years_experience: 10 Years

A Facility Manager meets with government personnel designated by the Contracting Officer to discuss facility operations and maintenance activities, observes all work in progress, and ensures work is performed in accordance with the performance contract. A Facility Manager also supports commissioning, quality assurance, and maintenance turnover activities.

A Facility Manager, Assistant supports the proper implementation of maintenance programs and makes overall work assignments for all contract and regular employees, allocating available resources to various projects.

raw_data.title: Facility Operators, Lead2
raw_data.description: A Facility Operator, Lead is responsible for the day-to-day operation of all facility equipment and supervises all subcontractors and facility personnel with regard to the equipment operation and maintenance on campuses.  A Facility Operator, Lead monitors the operation of major plant equipment and systems that support delivery of energy to the customer, leads and assists the troubleshooting of equipment and process issues, and ensures compliance with all environmental regulatory requirements. A Facility Operator, Lead also oversees the site safety program by ensuring all regulatory and company rules are adhered to at the site, training employees, reporting and investigating incidents/ injuries, implementing programs to enhance the safety culture, and personally observing safe work practices and adhering to all safety requirement.

raw_data.description: A Facility Operator ensures proper operation of boilers, chillers, generation, and other major plant equipment. Duties include properly starting and shutting down equipment and observing and interpreting readings on gauges, meters, and charts that register various aspects of boiler or other equipment operation.  A Facility Operator adjusts controls to ensure safe and efficient equipment operation that meets the demand for utilities. A Facility Operator also performs general maintenance and repairs of equipment and buildings on  campuses requiring practical skills and knowledge.

raw_data.title: Engineers, Senior
raw_data.description: The Sr. Performance Engineer is an engineer that has exhibited outstanding performance in both project delivery, and the advancement of ESG ideals, thus designated as someone to emulate.  A Sr. Performance Engineer has all the same responsibilities as a Performance Engineer, with the additional responsibility to mentor other engineers.  The Performance Engineer is the primary technical project developer with in a ESG region. As the primary resource for technical expertise, Account Executives and Regional management count on Performance Engineers to be responsible for understanding the technical needs and wants of a customer, then turning that information into accurate concrete solutions. Performance Engineers may deal with technical issues that include but not limited to facility energy consumption analysis and reduction strategies, general capital improvements, and even large scale community infrastructure projects.  The Performance Engineer is not only responsible for the technical strategies, but the costing of projects, forecasting energy reduction for a given solution if applicable, creating a plan to measure and verify the energy reductions forecasted, presentation of findings and solutions to customers and mangers, and to assist the delivery team to ensure smooth installations and achieve exceptional results for the customer
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Must be a current Performance Engineer with at least ten (10) years’ experience
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Professional Engineer (PE) Professional Engineering license from the following fields: ,CEM, CMVP, Any LEED Certification, NEBB, TAB, Any ASHRAE Certification

labor_categories.years_experience: Must be a current Performance Engineer with at least ten (10) years’ experience

raw_data.title: Energy Engineer

The Energy Engineer works with a regional engineering team to complete specific tasks on energy conservation, capital improvement, and infrastructure projects through multiple forms of procurement including, Performance Contracting.  Examples of typical tasks given to the Energy Engineers may include, but not limited to, are utility bill data entry and analysis, auditing a facility and creating equipment inventories, escorting contractors through facilities, and general energy calculations

It shall be the function of this individual to gather ongoing facility information and make recommendations for energy cost reduction and, with consent, implement certain measures for utility cost reduction.

raw_data.title: Superintendent (lighting)
raw_data.description: Lighting Construction Superintendent coordinates all aspects of project execution of the Lighting scope of work, ensuring a smooth transition from the design phase to the installation and on-going service and support phase of the completed project. This includes, but is not limited to, advising and assisting the Lighting Engineer in estimating and managing the account, conferring with engineering personnel on technical information, procuring and managing outside contractors, scheduling project phases and training customers’ maintenance personnel. The Lighting Construction Superintendent acts as primary point of contact for all internal personnel, external contractors, subcontractors and customer agents to coordinate all aspects of project installation. Ensures that projects are completed on time, within budget and that customers are satisfied with both the installation process and the end result.  The Lighting Construction Superintendent must be able to communicate effectively with both ESG Project Manager and the customer. The Lighting Construction Superintendent must have a working knowledge of lighting systems, the scope of work, and be able to trouble shoot lighting issues and report to the Lighting Engineer. The Lighting Construction Superintendent will be the point person on site during installation and will be responsible for all the day-to-day operations in the field.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Basic knowledge of major facility equipment (chillers, boilers, air handlers, lighting systems, etc.)

labor_categories.years_experience: Basic knowledge of major facility equipment (chillers, boilers, air handlers, lighting systems, etc.)

raw_data.title: Sr. Lighting Application Specialist
raw_data.description: The Sr. Lighting Application Specialist is a person that has knowledge and proficiency in current commercial lighting systems, industry trends, lighting design, lighting controls and associated technologies.  A Sr. Lighting Application Specialist will have the responsibility to audit and develop solutions that support a cost effective solutions for our customers, which include but are not limited to K-12 Schools, Universities, Hospitals, Municipalities, State Agencies, and Federal Agencies. Application of lighting includes both interior and exterior lighting solutions.  The Sr. Lighting Application Specialist is a technical project developer within ESG’s lighting program that reports to and works closely with the Sr. Lighting Engineer.  The Sr. Lighting Application Specialist needs to be responsible for understanding the technical needs and wants of a customer, then turning that information into accurate concrete solutions. Lighting Engineers/Designers may deal with technical issues that include but are not limited to facility energy consumption analysis and reduction strategies, general capital improvements, and even large-scale community lighting projects. The Sr. Lighting Application Specialist is not only responsible for the technical strategies, but the costing of projects, the provision of life cycle analysis of proposed systems both from an energy and operational stand point, and assisting the delivery team to ensure smooth installations and achieve exceptional results for the customer.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Bachelor’s Degree from an accredited four-year college or university with minimum five years’ construction related experience in Lighting Projects

labor_categories.years_experience: Bachelor’s Degree from an accredited four-year college or university with minimum five years’ construction related experience in Lighting Projects

This includes, but is not limited to, advising and assisting the Lighting Engineer in estimating and managing the account, conferring with engineering personnel on technical information, procuring and managing outside contractors, scheduling project phases and training customers’ maintenance personnel. The Lighting Application Specialist acts as primary point of contact for all internal personnel, external contractors, subcontractors and customer agents to coordinate all aspects of project installation. Ensures that projects are completed on time, within budget and that customers are satisfied with both the installation process and the end result.

raw_data.title: Director (lighting)
raw_data.description: The Lighting Director position is a high level role responsible for directing, coaching, and leading a team of lighting professionals in a fast paced and growing environment.  This position will manage many people of various skillsets and must demonstrate the ability to work with all types of personalities and remain calm under pressure and stress.  The Lighting Director needs to understand the LED lighting retrofit business, understand and work with ESG internal customers in a professional and ethical manner, and must be able to sell our team and promote our abilities to grow the business.  Setting goals for performance and financial are the responsibility of the Lighting Director.  It is the responsibility of the Lighting Director to manage and achieve the goals and expectations on a yearly basis.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: 10 - 15 years’ related industry experience; previous construction managerial experience.
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: CLEP

raw_data.title: Engineers, Development II
raw_data.description: An Engineer, Development II supports regional engineering efforts and is responsible for overseeing execution of the development process including daily interactions with the Engineer, Development Engineer I's, Engineers, and any other support personnel utilized in the development effort.  An Engineer, Development II conducts initial site surveys to identify inefficiencies related to energy systems, facility infrastructure, and system operations providing the framework for the projects to be developed.  An Engineer, Development II oversees in-depth development surveys and is responsible for final technical portion of the proposal. An Engineer, Development II reviews and oversees the development of engineering designs and technical solutions, detailed energy savings calculations, operational savings calculations, life cycle cost analyses, and feasibility analyses. An Engineer, Development II works closely with Project Managers, Engineer, Development I's, Engineers, and M&V Engineers to ensure a smooth development process, transition to installation and ultimately a productive performance period effort. An Engineer, Development II is the communication link for technical information between the internal ESG teams and the customer.  An Engineer, Development II identifies and works with subcontractors, consultants, and vendors to provide technical analysis and descriptions for project installation and to ensure the quality of work delivered exceeds the job requirements.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Seven years of experience in construction or energy service related field or three years as an  Development Engineer I with ESG
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Prefer Professional Engineering license and at least one (1) certification from the following field:  CEM; CMVP; Any LEED Certification; NEBB; TAB; Any ASHRAE Certification.

labor_categories.years_experience: Seven years of experience in construction or energy service related field or three years as an  Development Engineer I with ESG

raw_data.title: Sr. Engineer (lighting)
raw_data.description: The Sr. Lighting Engineer is an engineer that has outstanding knowledge and proficiency in current commercial lighting systems, industry trends, lighting design, lighting controls and associated technologies.  The Sr. Lighting Engineer will have the responsibility to audit and develop solutions that support cost effective solutions for our customers which include but are not limited to: K-12 Schools, Universities, Hospitals, Municipalities, State Agencies, and Federal Agencies.  Application of lighting includes both interior and exterior lighting solutions.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: At least seven (7) years’ related experience
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: PE – (Professional Engineering license)

raw_data.title: Administrative Assistant**
raw_data.description: In addition to secretarial duties (filing, taking phone calls, scheduling appointments, making travel arrangements), this position will provide administrative support to executive staff with office management responsibilities to include budgeting, personnel records and payroll. The Administrative Assistant may be required to work independently on projects requiring research and preparation of briefing charts and other presentation materials.

labor_categories.years_experience: Five Years

raw_data.title: Secretary I**
raw_data.description: This position provides principal secretarial support in an office, usually to one individual, and, in some cases, to the subordinate staff of that individual. The Secretary maintains a close and highly responsive relationship to the day-to-day activities of the supervisor and staff, works fairly independently receiving a minimum of detailed supervision and guidance, and performs various clerical and secretarial duties requiring knowledge of office routine and an understanding of the organization, programs, and procedures related to the work of the office. Computers may exist in the environment, requiring working knowledge of certain office software programs.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Three Years

raw_data.title: Service Order Dispatcher**
raw_data.description: This position receives, records, and distributes work orders to service crews upon customers' requests for service on articles or utilities purchased from wholesale or retail establishment or utility company, records information, such as name, address, article to be repaired, or service to be rendered, prepares work order and distributes to service crew, schedules service calls and dispatches service crew. The Service Order Dispatcher calls or writes the customer to insure satisfactory performance of service, keeps record of service calls and work orders, may dispatch orders and relay messages and special instructions to mobile crews and other departments using radio or cellular telephone equipment.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Two Years

labor_categories.years_experience: Two Years

raw_data.title: Supply Technician**
raw_data.description: This position performs limited aspects of technical supply management work (e.g., inventory management, storage management, cataloging, and property utilization) related to depot, local, or other supply activities. Work usually is segregated by commodity area or function, and controlled in terms of difficulty, complexity, or responsibility. Assignments usually relate to stable or standardized segments of technical supply management operations; or to functions or subjects that are narrow in scope or limited in difficulty. The work generally involves individual case problems or supply actions. This work may require consideration of program requirements together with specific variations in or from standardized guidelines. Assignments require:(a) a good working knowledge of the governing supply systems, programs, policies, nomenclature, work methods, manuals, or other established guidelines; (b) an understanding of the needs of the organization serviced; and (c) analytical ability to define or recognize the dimension of the problems involved, to collect the necessary data to establish the facts, and take or recommend action
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Two years

labor_categories.years_experience: Two years

raw_data.title: Switchboard Operator/Receptionist**
raw_data.description: This position greets visitors, determining nature of visits and directing visitors to appropriate persons. Duties may include, but are not limited to, relaying incoming, outgoing, and intra-system calls through a private branch exchange (PBX) system; recording and transmitting messages; keeping records of calls placed; providing information to callers and visitors; hearing and resolving complaints; making appointments; handling incoming and outgoing mail; controlling access to the facility; keeping a log of visitors; and issuing visitor passes. In this position, one may also type and perform other routine clerical work, such as entering data and processing documents, which may occupy the major portion of the worker's time.”

raw_data.title: Janitor**
raw_data.description: The Janitor cleans and keeps in an orderly condition factory working areas and washrooms, or premises of an office, apartment house, or commercial or other establishment. Duties involve a combination of the following: Sweeping, mopping or scrubbing, and polishing floors; removing chips, trash, and other refuse; dusting equipment, furniture, or fixtures; polishing metal fixtures or trimmings; providing supplies and minor maintenance services; and cleaning lavatories, showers, and restrooms. Excluded area. Workers who specialize in window washing. Housekeeping staff who make beds and change linens as a primary responsibility. Workers required to disassemble and assemble equipment in order to clean machinery. Workers who receive additional compensation to maintain sterile facilities or equipment.

raw_data.title: Laborer, Grounds Maintenance**
raw_data.description: The Laborer, Grounds Maintenance maintains grounds of industrial, commercial or public property such as buildings, camp and picnic grounds, parks, playgrounds, greenhouses, and athletic fields, and repairs structures and equipment, performing one or more of the following tasks: cut grass, using walking-type or riding mowers (less than 2000 lbs.), trim hedges and edges around walks, flowerbeds, and wells, using hedge trimmers, clippers and edging tools, prunes shrubs and trees to shape and improve growth, using shears and other hand tools, sprays lawn, shrubs, and trees with fertilizer or insecticide. Job duties also include the following: planting grass, flowers, trees, and shrubs, watering lawn and shrubs during dry periods, using hose or activating sprinkler system, picks up and burns or carts away leaves, paper or other litter; removing snow from walks, driveways, roads, or parking lots, using shovel and snow blower, spreads salt on walkways and other areas, repairing and painting fences, gates, benches, tables, guardrails, and outbuildings. This Worker assists in repair of roads, walks, buildings, and mechanical equipment, and may clean comfort stations, offices workshop areas, and parking lots by sweeping, washing, mopping and polishing.

raw_data.title: System Support Specialist**
raw_data.description: This position provides troubleshooting assistance and problem resolution for computer systems in a variety of environments. Such assistance and resolution is provided for personal computers, mini/mainframe computers, client-servers as well Local Area Networks (LANs), Wide Area Networks (WANs), and web pages.

raw_data.title: Central Controls System Technician**
raw_data.description: This position provides troubleshooting assistance and problem resolution for computer systems in a variety of environments. Such assistance and resolution is provided for personal computers, mini/mainframe computers, client-servers as well Local Area Networks (LANs), Wide Area Networks (WANs), and web pages.

raw_data.title: Engineers, Development I

An Engineer, Development I employs the foundational technical methods used to create performance contracting projects and helps to identify inefficiencies related to energy systems, facility infrastructure, and system operations. An Engineer, Development I executes site audits to gather information, develops initial technical solutions, and performs detailed energy and operational savings calculations as part of the feasibility analysis.

raw_data.title: Stock Clerk**
raw_data.description: The Stock Clerk receives, stores, and issues equipment, materials, supplies, merchandise, food stuffs, or tools, and compiles stock records of items in stockroom, warehouse or storage yard. This worker sorts, or weighs incoming articles to verify receipt of items on requisition or invoice, examines stock to verify conformance to specifications, stores articles in bins, on floor or on shelves, according to identifying information, such as style, size or type of material, fills orders or issues supplies from stock, prepares periodic, special or perpetual inventory of stock, and requisitions articles to fill incoming orders. This worker also compiles reports on use of stock handling equipment, adjustments of inventory counts and stock records, spoilage of or damage to stock, location changes, and refusal of shipments, may mark identifying codes, figures, or letters on articles, may distribute stock among production workers, keeping records of material issued, may make adjustments or repairs to articles carried in stock, and may cut stock to site to fill order.

raw_data.title: Tools And Parts Attendant**
raw_data.description: This incumbent receives, stores, and issues hand tools, machine tools, dies, replacement parts, shop supplies and equipment, such as measuring devices, in an industrial establishment. The Tools and Parts Attendant does the following: keeps records of tools issued to and returned by workers, searches for lost or misplaced tools, prepares periodic inventory or keeps perpetual inventory and requisitions stock as needed, unpacks and stores new equipment; visually inspects tools or measures with micrometer for wear or defects and reports damaged or worn-out equipment to superiors; may coat tools with grease or other preservative, using a brush or spray gun, and may attach identification tags or engrave identifying information on tools and equipment using electric marking tool.

raw_data.title: Appliance Mechanic**
raw_data.description: The Appliance Mechanic installs, services and repairs stoves, refrigerators, dishwashing machines, and other electrical household or commercial appliances, using hand tools, test equipment and following wiring diagrams and manufacturer's specifications. This person connects appliance to power source and test meters, such as wattmeter, ammeter, or voltmeter, observes readings on meters and graphic recorders, examines appliance during operating cycle to detect excess vibration, overheating, fluid leaks and loose parts, and disassembles appliances and examines mechanical and electrical parts. The worker traces electrical circuits, following diagram and locates shorts and grounds, using ohmmeter, calibrates timers, thermostats and adjusts contact points, and cleans and washes parts, using wire brush, buffer, and solvent to remove carbon, grease and dust. This person replaces worn or defective parts, such as switches, pumps, bearings, transmissions, belts, gears, blowers and defective wiring, repairs and adjusts appliance motors, reassembles appliance, adjusts pulleys and lubricates moving parts, using hand tools and lubricating equipment.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Three years
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Journeyman's license, military occupational design, or equivalent professional certification.

raw_data.title: Electrician, Maintenance**
raw_data.description: An Electrician performs a variety of electrical trade functions such as the installation, maintenance, or repair of equipment for the generation, distribution, or utilization of electric energy. Work involves most of the following: installing or repairing any of a variety of electrical equipment such as generators, transformers, switchboards, controllers, circuit breakers, motors, heating units, conduit systems, or other transmission equipment; working from blueprints, drawings, layouts, or other specifications, locating and diagnosing trouble in the electrical system or equipment, working standard computations relating to load requirements of wiring or electrical equipment, and using a variety of electrician's hand tools and measuring and testing instruments. In general, the work of the maintenance electrician requires rounded training and experience usually acquired through a formal apprenticeship or equivalent training and experience.

raw_data.title: Electronics Technician Maintenance III**
raw_data.description: The Electronics Technician Maintenance III applies advanced technical knowledge to solve complex problems that typically cannot be solved solely by referencing manufacturers' manuals or similar documents. Examples of such problems include determining the location and density of circuitry, evaluating electromagnetic radiation, isolating malfunctions, and incorporating engineering; changes. Work typically requires an understanding of the interrelationships of circuits, exercising independent judgment in performing such tasks as making circuit analyses, calculating wave forms, and tracing relationships in signal flow, using complex test instruments such as high frequency pulse generators, frequency synthesizers, distortion analyzers, and complex computer control equipment. Work may be reviewed by supervisor for general compliance with accepted practices. This position may provide technical guidance to lower level technicians.

raw_data.title: General Maintenance Worker**
raw_data.description: The General Maintenance Worker performs general maintenance and repair of equipment and buildings requiring practical skill and knowledge (but not proficiency) in such trades as painting, carpentry, plumbing, masonry, and electrical work. Work involves a variety of the following duties: replacing electrical receptacles, wires, switches, fixtures, and motors, using plaster or compound to patch minor holes and cracks in walls and ceilings, repairing or replacing sinks, water coolers, and toilets painting structures and equipment; repairing or replacing concrete floors, steps, and sidewalks, replacing damaged paneling and floor tiles, hanging doors and installing door locks, replacing broken window panes, and performing general maintenance on equipment and machinery. Excluded are: a. Craft workers included in a formal apprenticeship or progression program based on training and experience; b. Skilled craft workers required to demonstrate proficiency in one or more trades; c. Workers performing simple maintenance duties not requiring practical skill and knowledge of a trade (e.g., changing light bulbs and replacing faucet washers).

raw_data.title: HVAC Preventative Maintenance Technician**
raw_data.description: Performs general maintenance and repair of equipment and buildings requiring practical skill and knowledge (but not proficiency) in such trades as painting, carpentry, plumbing, masonry, and electrical work. Work involves a variety of the following duties: replacing electrical receptacles, wires, switches, fixtures, and motors, using plaster or compound to patch minor holes and cracks in walls and ceilings, repairing or replacing sinks, water coolers, and toilets painting structures and equipment; repairing or replacing concrete floors, steps, and sidewalks, replacing damaged paneling and floor tiles, hanging doors and installing door locks, replacing broken window panes, and performing general maintenance on equipment and machinery. Excluded are: a. Craft workers included in a formal apprenticeship or progression program based on training and experience; b. Skilled craft workers required to demonstrate proficiency in one or more trades; c. Workers performing simple maintenance duties not requiring practical skill and knowledge of a trade (e.g., changing light bulbs and replacing faucet washers). Assists one or more workers in the skilled maintenance trades by performing specific or general duties of lesser skill such as: keeping a worker supplied with materials and tools, cleaning working area, machine, and equipment; assisting journeyman by holding materials or tools; and performing other unskilled tasks as directed by journeyman. The kind of work the helper is permitted to perform varies from trade to trade. In some trades the helper is confined to supplying, lifting, and holding materials and tools, and cleaning working areas and in others, the worker is permitted to perform specialized machine operations, or parts of a trade that are also performed by workers on a full-time basis.

raw_data.title: Heating Ventilation And Air-Conditioning  Mechanic**
raw_data.description: The Heating, Ventilation, and Air-Conditioning Mechanic installs, services and repairs environmental-control systems in residences, department stores, office buildings, and other commercial establishments, utilizing knowledge of refrigeration theory, pipefitting and structural layout, mounts compressor and condenser units on platform or floor, using hand tools, following blueprints or engineering specifications, fabricates, assembles and installs ductwork and chassis parts, using portable metalworking tools and welding equipment, and installsevaporator unit in chassis or in air-duct system, using hand tools. This mechanic also cuts and bends tubing to correct length and shape, using cutting and bending equipment and tools, cuts and threads pipe, using machine-threading or hand-threading equipment, joins tubing or pipes to various refrigerating units by means of sleeves, couplings or unions, and solders joints, using torch, forming complete circuit for refrigerant, installs expansion and discharge valves in circuit.This worker connects motors, compressors, temperature controls, humidity controls, and circulating ventilation fans to control panels and connects control panels to power source; installs air and water filters in completed installation, injects small amount of refrigerant into compressor to test systems and adds Freon gas to build up prescribed operating pressure. This mechanic observes pressure and vacuum gauges and adjusts controls to insure proper operation, tests joints and connections for gas leaks, using gauges or soap-and-water solution, wraps pipes in insulation batting and secures them in place with cement or wire bands, replaces defective breaker controls, thermostats, switches, fuses and electrical wiring to repair installed units, may install, repair and service air conditioners, ranging from fifteen to twenty tons cooling capacity in warehouses and small factory buildings.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Journeyman's license, military occupational designation, or equivalent professional certification. EPA refrigerant recovery certification.

labor_categories.years_experience: Five years

raw_data.title: Heating Ventilation And Air Conditioning  Mechanic (Research Facility)**
raw_data.description: The Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning Mechanic (Research Facility) installs, modifies and repairs refrigeration - hermetic, semi-hermetic, mechanical, screw, scroll and centrifugal units to 1100 tons; air conditioning, ventilation; reverse osmosis systems, computer rooms; process coolers; ice machines; evaporative cooling; air compressing and related control systems, including pneumatic, DDC, and building control systems equipment. This person performs difficult installation tasks involving assembly, testing, calibrating, and adjusting of temperature control and environmental control systems such as air conditioning plants, air environmental control systems, air distribution systems and complex dual equipment cooling installations, specialized refrigerated warehouses and facilities, and evaporative mechanical ventilation, and dehumidification systems.The Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning Mechanic (Research Facility) installs new or repaired component and performs complex modifications of systems and components in accordance with applicable electrical publications and directives, and will maintain and repair specialized laboratory equipment such as fume hoods, de-ionized water systems, bio-clean systems, vacuum systems, cascade refrigeration systems, and laboratory sinks. This mechanic may perform complex repair of systems component such as compressors, condensers, heat pumps regulators, fluid and refrigerant gas lines valves, meters, gages, thermostats, pumps, mechanical linkage, and electrical sensing, switching and controlling devices including pneumatic controls, variable speed drives, digital controlled devices, electronic, hydraulic heating and cooling and economizer systems.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years

raw_data.title: Engineering Designers

An Engineering Designer may also perform RS Means cost estimates, produce product/equipment selections, as required, for assigned projects, produce scaled site and floor plans for projects, and produce equipment drawings.

raw_data.title: Laborer**
raw_data.description: The Laborer performs tasks that require mainly physical abilities and effort involving little or no specialized skill or prior work experience. The following tasks are typical of this occupation: The Laborer loads and unloads trucks, andother conveyances, moves supplies and materials to proper location by wheelbarrow or hand truck; stacks materials for storage or binning, collects refuse and salvageable materials, and digs, fills, and tamps earth excavations. The Laborer levels ground using pick, shovel, tamper and rake, shovels concrete and snow; cleans culverts and ditches, cuts tree and brush; operates power lawnmowers, moves and arranges heavy pieces of office and household furniture, equipment, and appliance, moves heavy pieces of automotive, medical engineering, and other types of machinery and equipment, spreads sand and salt on icy roads and walkways, and picks up leaves and trash.

raw_data.title: Machinery Maintenance Mechanic**
raw_data.description: The Machinery Maintenance Mechanic repairs machinery or mechanical equipment. Work involves most of the following: examining machines and mechanical equipment to diagnose source of trouble, dismantling or partly dismantling machines and performing repairs that mainly involve the use of hand tools in scraping and fitting parts. Responsibilities include replacing broken or defective parts with items obtained from stock, and ordering the production of a replacement part by a machine shop or sending the machine to a machine shop for major repairs. Duties also include preparing written specifications for major repairs or for the production of parts ordered from machine shops, reassembling machines and making all necessary adjustments for operation. In general, the work of a Machinery Maintenance Mechanic requires rounded training and experience usually acquired through a formal apprenticeship or equivalent training and experience. Excluded from this classification are workers whose primary duties involve setting up or adjusting machines.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Journeyman's license, military occupational designation, or equivalent professional certification.

The kind of work the helper is permitted to perform varies from trade to trade. In some trades the helper is confined to supplying, lifting, and holding materials and tools, and cleaning working areas and in others, the worker is permitted to perform specialized machine operations, or parts of a trade that are also performed by workers on a full-time basis.

raw_data.title: Pipefitter Maintenance**
raw_data.description: The Pipefitter, Maintenance installs or repairs water, steam, gas or other types of pipe and pipefitting. Work involves most of the following: laying out work and measuring to locate position of pipe from drawings or other written specifications, cutting various sizes of pipe to correct lengths with chisel and hammer, oxyacetylene torch or pipe-cutting machines, threading pipe with stocks and dies. This person is responsible for bending pipe by hand-driven or power-driven machines, assembling pipe with couplings and fastening pipe to hangers, making standard shop computations relating to pressures, flow and size of pipe required; and making standard tests to determine whether finished pipes meet specifications. In general, the work of the Maintenance Pipefitter requires rounded training and experience usually acquired through a formal apprenticeship or equivalent training and experience. Workers primarily engaged in installing and repairing building sanitation or heating systems are excluded.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Journeyman's license, military occupational designation, or equivalent professional certification

raw_data.title: Plumber Maintenance**
raw_data.description: The Plumber, Maintenance assembles, installs and repairs pipes, fittings and fixtures of heating, water, and drainage systems, according to specifications and plumbing codes, studies building plans and working drawings to determine work aids required, and sequence of installations. This worker inspects structure to ascertain obstructions to be avoided to prevent weakening of structure resulting from installation of pipe, and locates and marks position of pipe and pipe connections and passage holes for pipes in walls and floors. This worker cuts openings in walls and floors to accommodate pipe and pipe fittings, using hand tools and power tools, cuts and threads pipe, using pipe cutters, cutting torch, and pipe-threading machine, bends pipe to required angle by use of pipe-bending machine, or by placing pipe over block and bending it by hand. The Plumber, Maintenance assembles and installs valves, pipefittings, and pipes composed of metals, such as iron, steel, brass and lead, and nonmetals, such as glass, vitrified clay, and plastic. This person joins pipe by use of screws, bolts, fittings, solder, plastic solvent, and caulks joints, fills pipe system with water or air and reads pressure gauges to determine whether system is leaking, installs and repairs plumbing fixtures, such as sinks, commodes, bathtubs, water heaters, hot water tanks, garbage disposal units, dishwashers, and water softeners. This person repairs and maintains plumbing by replacing washers in leaky faucets, mending burst pipes, and opening clogged drains, and may weld holding fixtures to steel structural members.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Journeyman's license, military occupational designation, or equivalent professional certification

Work involves most of the following: planning and laying out all types of sheet-metal maintenance work from blueprints, models, or other specifications, setting up and operating all available types of sheet-metal working machines, using a variety of hand tools in cutting, bending, forming, shaping, fitting and assembling, and installing sheet-metal articles as required. In general, the work of the maintenance sheet-metal worker requires rounded training and experience usually acquired through a formal apprenticeship or equivalent training and experience.

raw_data.title: Boiler Tender**

This incumbent may also do one or more of the following: maintain a log in which various aspects of boiler operation are recorded; clean, oil, make minor repairs or assist in repair to boiler room equipment; and following prescribed methods, treat boiler water with chemicals and analyze boiler water for such things as acidity, causticity, and alkalinity.

raw_data.title: Sewage Plant Operator**
raw_data.description: This incumbent operates sewage treatment, sludge processing, and disposal equipment in wastewater (sewage) treatment plant to control flow and processing of sewage, monitors control panels and adjusts valves and gates manually or by remote control to regulate flow of sewage, observes variations in operating conditions and interprets meter and gauge readings, and tests results to determine load requirements. This worker starts and stops pumps, engines, and generators to control flow of raw sewage through filtering, settling, aeration, and sludge digestion processes, maintains log of operations and records meter and gas readings, gives directions to wastewater treatment-plant attendants and sewage-disposal workers in performing routine operations and maintenance, and may collect sewage sample, using dipper or bottle and conduct laboratory tests, using testing equipment, such as colorimeter. This person may operate and maintain power-generating equipment to provide steam and electricity for plant.

raw_data.title: Stationary Engineer**
raw_data.description: The Stationary Engineer operates and maintains one or more systems that provide an establishment with such services as heat, air-conditioning (cool, humidify, dehumidify, filter, and circulate air), refrigeration, steam or high-temperature water or electricity. Duties involve: observing and interpreting readings on gauges, meters and charts which register various aspects of the system's operation, adjusting controls to insure safe and efficient operation of the system and to meet demands for the service provided, recording in logs various aspects of the system's operation, keeping the engines, machinery and equipment of the system in good working order. This engineer may direct and coordinate activities of other workers (not stationary engineers) in performing tasks directly related to operating and maintaining the system or systems. The classification excludes head or chief engineers in establishments employing more than one engineer. Workers are required to be skilled in the repair of electronic control equipment; workers in establishments producing electricity, steam, or heated or cooled air primarily for sale, and Boiler Tenders.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Journeyman's license, military occupational designation, or equivalent professional certification

labor_categories.years_experience: Five years

raw_data.title: Engineers, M&V
raw_data.description: An Engineer, M&V confers with the project team during the proposal development phase to ensure application of the most appropriate M&V options consistent with IPMVP and FEMP guidelines and develops a sound baseline from which energy savings can be derived. An Engineer, M&V will also lead the preparation of the M&V Plan, administer post-construction and performance period measurements and analysis, and ensure M&V work and reports are prepared properly and timely. Additionally, an Engineer, M&V will verify changes in facility operation or mission and make recommendations to optimize savings potential. This position is part of an independent M&V business function that reports directly to senior management.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five or more years of performance contracting M&V experience, federal preferred (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

labor_categories.years_experience: Five or more years of performance contracting M&V experience, federal preferred (or equivalent combination of experience and education)

raw_data.title: Generator Technician**
raw_data.description: Operates and maintains one or more systems that provide an establishment with such services as heat, air-conditioning (cool, humidify, dehumidify, filter, and circulate air), refrigeration, steam or high-temperature water or electricity. Duties involve: observing and interpreting readings on gauges, meters and charts which register various aspects of the system's operation, adjusting controls to insure safe and efficient operation of the system and to meet demands for the service provided, recording in logs various aspects of the system's operation, keeping the engines, machinery and equipment of the system in good working order. This engineer may direct and coordinate activities of other workers (not stationary engineers) in performing tasks directly related to operating and maintaining the system or systems. The classification excludes head or chief engineers in establishments employing more than one engineer. Workers are required to be skilled in the repair of electronic control equipment; workers in establishments producing electricity, steam, or heated or cooled air primarily for sale, and Boiler Tenders.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Journeyman's license, military occupational designation, or equivalent professional certification

labor_categories.years_experience: Five years

raw_data.title: Ventilation Equipment Tender**
raw_data.description: This incumbent tends ventilating and heating equipment, such as fans, vacuum pumps, air compressors, vents and ducts, and lubrication-oil coolers used in buildings or industrial processes; adjusts valves to regulate temperature of lubrication oil and flow of water through system, moves controls to regulate speed of fans, adjust vents and ducts, records gauge readings, and repairs completed, and time lost because of inoperative equipment. This worker writes repair work order tickets and out-of-order tags preparatory to equipment repair, inspects equipment to detect excessive noise and heat, replaces gauges and tightens and chalks leaky fittings, using wrenches, hammers, and chalking tool, cleans carbon deposits, pitch, and grease from fans, vents and ducts, using scrapers, hammer, and compressed air or steam.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Journeyman's license, military occupational designation, or equivalent professional certification

labor_categories.years_experience: Five years

raw_data.title: Water Treatment Plant Operator**
raw_data.description: This position controls treatment plant machines and equipment to purify and clarify water for human consumption and for industrial use. This person operates and controls electric motors, pumps, and valves to regulate flow of raw water into treating plant and dumps specified amounts of chemicals such as chlorine, ammonia, and lime into water, or adjusts automatic devices that admit specified amounts of chemicals into tanks to disinfect, deodorize, and clarify water. This person starts agitators to mix chemicals and allows impurities to settle to bottom of tank, turns valves to regulate water through filter beds to remove impurities, pumps purified water into water mains, monitors panel board and adjusts controls to regulator flow rates, loss of head pressure and water elevation and distribution of water. This operator cleans tanks and filter beds, using backwashing (reverse flow of water), repairs and lubricates machines and equipment, using hand- and power tools, tests water samples to determine acidity, color, and impurities, using colorimeter, turbidimeter, and conductivity meter. Work includes dumping chemicals such as alum into tanks to coagulate impurities and reduce acidity, recording data, such as residual content of chemicals, water turbidity, and water pressure. This operator may operate portable water-purification plant to supply drinking water, and purify wastewater from plant preparatory to pumping water into rivers and streams or city mains.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Five years
raw_data.required_certifications_or_licenses: Journeyman's license, military occupational designation, or equivalent professional certification

labor_categories.years_experience: Five years

raw_data.title: Analyst, M&V
raw_data.description: The Measurement and Verification (M&V) Analyst will be a member of the M&V Team.  The M&V Analyst must be a highly capable, detail oriented individual. The Measurement and Verification Analyst is responsible for the on-going monitoring, verification, and reporting of savings associated with energy savings guarantees.  This individual must be self-motivated and able to work independently, but must also possess the ability to effectively interface with many internal & external customers on a daily basis.  Other job duties include any other departmental assignments as directed by the Manager of Measurement and Verification. This is a full-time salaried position reporting to the Manager of Measurement and Verification.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Bachelor’s degree from an accredited university or college in business, law, finance, engineering, math or related field, or five or more years verified experience in energy or building or facility management, or measurement and verification

labor_categories.years_experience: Bachelor’s degree from an accredited university or college in business, law, finance, engineering, math or related field, or five or more years verified experience in energy or building or facility management, or measurement and verification

raw_data.title: Operations Managers II
raw_data.description: An Operations Manager II provides direct managerial support to two or more Operations Teams made up of Project Managers and Construction Managers for large, complex projects that include multi-site, multi-energy conversation measures (ECM’s) for mission critical customers . The Operations Manager directs and coordinates activities of the operations personnel and consultants to ensure projects are on schedule, compliant with all applicable FAR / DFARS requirements, and energy savings and performance guarantees, and within prescribed budgets. The Operations Manager II provides guidance and advice in the selection of the subcontractors and vendors to deliver the project per ESG and mission critical customer requirements and standards, coordinates with governmental regulatory agencies, and works with the M&V department to ensure the obligations are being met and tracked appropriately.
raw_data.education_and_experience_substitution: Three (3) tyears related experience in performance contracting in the delivery side and two years management experience

labor_categories.years_experience: Three (3) tyears related experience in performance contracting in the delivery side and two years management experience
